answers.answer: This is not unusual.  You could still have some red blood cells freely floating in the fluid, and the gas bubble may not have absorbed yet, depending on which type of gas was used.  Also the condition which caused the vitreous hemorrhage may be accounting for some of the vision problem; that is, diabetes, macular degeneration, or retinal vein occlusion may have affected the central vision.  Ask your retina specialist about your progress at your next visit.

question: I have had hemorrhaging in the back of my eye which I have received injections to take care of it.  On my last injection on 6/21 after 2 days I got infection in my eye.  They tried testing the bacteria but nothing showed up.  After receiving an antibiotic injection it still didn't seem to clear up.  So the retina specialist scheduled me for a vitrectomy.  He removed the vitreous gel which had blood in it and removed most of a blood clot, removed bacteria and infection on 6/26, they also replaced the gel with an air bubble.  The redness and the infection seems to be mostly gone, but I still have not gotten back my vision.  It is like I have a fog or some sort of liquid in there. Is it common to take this long for the vision to return? It has been 2 weeks since the surgery.
title: vitrectomy
